docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare officials have accused health maintenance organizations of sending false information to their elderly subscribers in an effort to mobilize them to pressure Congress. In response, federal officials have begun demanding that H.M.O.'s submit newsletters and other documents to the government for review before sending them to Medicare beneficiaries. In this way, the government says, it will be able to ''correct any misstatements or misleading information.''

headline.main: U.S. Demands to Review Medicare Mailings by H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: Health Care Financing Administration accuses health maintenance organizations of sending false information to their Medicare subscribers in an effort to mobilize them to pressure Congress; demands that HMO's submit newletters and other documents to the government before sending them to Medicare beneficiaries; threatens fines and other penalties for HMO's who mislead beneficiaries; health plans defend mailings; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE life insurance industry is battening down its hatches -- and consumers, it turns out, will pay the price. Until recently, prices for term life, the most popular kind of life insurance, had been declining for more than a decade. But new regulations requiring insurers across the country to set aside more money to cover their potential payouts have caused rates for many policies to jump 20 to 50 percent.

headline.main: Term Life: The Safety Net Comes at a Higher Price

docs.abstract: New regulations requiring insurers across the country to set aside more money to cover potential payouts have resulted in rates for term life policies rising 20 to 50 percent; regulations, which do not affect whole life policies, are being adopted state by state, bringing prices elsewhere in the country closer to levels in New York State, where prices have long been highest in the nation; most experts say basic question to ask about the need for life insurance is whether your death will leave your dependends in financial lurch; various strategies for buying life insurance discussed; chart on premiums charged by some insurers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Millennium, schmillennium. It's the Year of the Dragon, baby. And among Asian-Americans who abide by the lunar calendar, this auspicious season of the mythical beast is also turning out to be the year of the baby boom.

headline.main: Year of the Dragon And the Diaper Pail; Favored Sign of Lunar Calendar Inspires an Asian Baby Boomlet

docs.abstract: Many Asian-Americans have apparently timed pregnancies to lunar calendar's Year of Dragon, which began Feb 5 and is deemed auspicious birth year; increased numbers of pregnancies in New York City's Asian neighborhoods noted; photo; drawings; chart of lunar years (M)
docs.snippet: Millennium, schmillennium.     It's the Year of the Dragon, baby. And among Asian-Americans who abide by the lunar calendar, this auspicious season of the mythical beast is also turning out to be the year of the baby boom.

docs.lead_paragraph: DR. DAVID M. NGANELE would like to do in Westchester what he recently began doing in Harlem -- running full-time educational programs so African-Americans and other minorities can get better health care. Dr. Nganele (pronounced GAN-ih-lay), who received his Ph.D. in physiology from New York Medical College in Valhalla, gave up a job a year ago at Pfizer to start, with its financial support, a health-education program at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem. His company, Harmony Health Communications in Harrison, is affiliated with North General Hospital and plans to establish a library on health issues. It is an attempt to overcome more than just financial barriers to good health care. Minorities, he said, distrust the white-dominated medical profession.

headline.main: Q&A/Dr. David M. Nganele; Leading Minorities to Better Health Care

docs.abstract: Interview with Dr David M Nganele, head of Harmony Health Communications in Harrison, NY, which runs health education programs aimed at blacks and other minorities; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FOR Connecticut's gay and lesbian state employees, the extension of health and pension benefits to their partners and children fills a long-awaited need. It means that Darlene Poudrier, a teacher in a state program for mentally retarded children and their families, will never again have to watch her partner delay back surgery because of the expense.

headline.main: State's Gay Employees Gain in Benefits Ruling

docs.abstract: Coalition of unions representing about 90 percent of Connecticut's state employees win contract arbitration with state over issue of same-sex domestic partners of state employees; ruling applies only to gay couples and does not affect employees in unmarried, opposite sex living arrangements; for state's gay and lesbian state employees, extension of health and pension benefits to their partners and children fills long-awaited need; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MAYBE they should call it unmanageable care. In just four frenetic years, the respected if somewhat stodgy insurance company once affectionately nicknamed Mother Aetna transformed itself into a colossal force in a much-criticized business, health plans. At the end of the rainbow there was supposed to be a gold mine of profits wrung from managing away the inefficiencies and excesses of modern medicine.

headline.main: Aetna Plans a Recovery; H.M.O.'s May Not Make It

docs.abstract: Profile of managed-care industry cites problems that have beset Aetna in discussing the outlook for the industry as a whole; Larry Feinberg, partner in NY-based healthcare hedge fund, notes managed care companies like Aetna have come under heavy attack in Congress, states and courts; notes Aetna alone is fending off at least nine class-action challenges to such fundamentals of managed care as use of financial incentives for doctors to keep costs down; says HMO's have also found their efforts to contain costs outfoxed by drug companies whose direct-to-consumer advertising stokes demand for expensive prescription druge, driving up health plans' drug costs; notes other factors, especially actions initiated by patients, that are resulting in health-care inflation returning to double-digit territory after several years of restraint; sketch; chart on how patients view managed care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: It is good to know that people who decide to forsake a BMW can get more personal attention from their doctors and avoid crowded waiting rooms (''For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns,'' front page, March 17). Of course, more doctors accepting only cash payments means even less attention and longer waits for the majority who depend on health insurance for medical care.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Boeing Company, battered by a 5 1/2-week strike by its engineers union that had delayed jet deliveries and helped send its stock price tumbling, announced a tentative agreement today to end the action. The walkout, which was one of the largest white-collar strikes against a company in years, had been trumpeted by national labor leaders as a crucial sign of their ability to organize professional workers.

headline.main: Tentative Pact Made to End Boeing Strike

docs.abstract: Boeing Co reaches tentative accord with Society of Professional Engineering Employees in Aerospace to end strike that has delayed jet deliveries; pact calls for 8 percent wage increase this year and 4.5 percent raises in next two years, as well as cash bonuses of up to $2,500; Boeing will distribute part of raises as merit pay; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns'' (front page, March 17): While I admire the courage of health care professionals who have opted out of our system in order to provide effective care, your article underscores the ethical failure of American health care. Health care based on need has been superseded by health care based on what one can afford. The less fortunate receive inferior care and the more than 44 million uninsured receive little or no care. Health maintenance organizations, managed care organizations, insurance companies and drug companies all operate on a legally mandated responsibility to maximize profits for shareholders.
docs.abstract: Arthur Reisel letter, commenting on March 17 article on doctors who have opted out of managed-care system in effort to provide more effective care for patients, says it underscores ethical failure of American health care (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns'' (front page, March 17): For doctors who treat Medicare patients, the switch to cash payments and up-front retainers can be perilous. The Medicare statute permits doctors to ''balance-bill'' patients over and above the Medicare payment. But if even one patient is converted to ''private pay'' status, the physician must agree not to seek reimbursement from the federal program for any Medicare beneficiary for two years. And breaking that promise can mean the physician cannot bill any Medicare beneficiary, even privately, for the remainder of the two-year period.
